McGinness Hills Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



It is Ormat Nevada, Inc.'s (Ormat's) policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. The McGinness Hills facility actively manages all operational permits and safety programs such as Nevada Division of Environmental Protection's Air Quality, Chemical Accident Prevention Program, Underground Injection Control programs as well as OSHA's Process Safety Management program. In addition, Ormat is ISO 14000 and 9001 certified and undergoes several audit processes to ensure all facilities are aggressively pursuing the highest quality, safety and environmental standards. Ormat is committed to handling the n-pentane systems in a safe manner to protect the environment. Copies of emergency response, process hazard analyses, Chemical Accident Prevention and process safety management plans and all technical drawing (P&IDS) for process equipment are maintained onsite for reference.



Facility Description

The McGinness Hills Geothermal Power Plant (McGinness Hills) is wholly owned by Ormat Nevada, Inc (Ormat), which is a division of Ormat Technologies, Inc., a publicly traded company. The power plant is located in Lander County on leases that encompass approximately 7,680 acres of public and private lands. The physical plant is located about 11 miles northeast of Austin, Nevada on Grass Valley Road. The leased acreage covers the defined geothermal resource area and receptive injection zones.



The physical address is:     1350 Grass Valley Road

            Austin, NV   89310

            

There are two, essentially identical processes within the power plant that comprises this stationary source.  McGinness Hills Phase I (MGH1) became operational in 2012.  McGinness Hills Phase II (MGH2) will become operational in January, 2015.



The processes are geothermal electric power generation facilities.  The process utilizes hot geothermal brine that is used to dr

ive an organic Rankine Cycle.  Specifically, each process consists of two, Integrated Two Level Unit (ITLU) air-cooled Ormat Energy Converter (OEC) units and one, level 3 air-cooled OEC.  Each OEC incorporates one double ended shaft generator driven by two 1800 RPM direct coupled special organic fluid turbines, and associated facilities. Geothermal brine is supplied from five production wells per process.  Spent geothermal fluid will be injected back into the subsurface reservoir via three injection wells per process.



McGinness Hills is operated by Ormat's Eastern Nevada Operations Group (ENOP).  The organization is comprised of management, administration, maintenance, engineering and operations personnel. ENOP operates four eastern Nevada power generation facilities owned by Ormat.



All the Eastern Nevada power plants operate continuously, 24 hours per day and 365 days per year (excluding scheduled maintenance downtime or plant upsets).   The McGinness Hills complex is staffed 24 hours per day and 365 days per year.  The remaining Eastern Nevada power plants are operated remotely from a central control room located at MGH1; however, personnel are always on site during the day shift at these locations.



Regulated Substance Handled

McGinness Hills stores n-pentane (CAS # 109-66-0) as the motive fluid used in the OEC units. In addition to the inventory present in the OECs, the plant has n-pentane storage tanks.  The tanks provide evacuation capacity that is necessary to facilitate removal of n-pentane from an OEC for maintenance activities. At MGH1, two tanks will have a nominal capacity of 30,000 gallons each (maximum fill capacity of 27,000 gallons) and one will have a nominal capacity of 12,000 gallons (maximum fill capacity of 10,800 gallons).  MGH2 has two, 36,000 gallon capacity tanks.  During normal operation, the tanks are essentially empty.  The registered quantities of n-pentane for each process include the quantity charged to each OEC plus a nominal

amount of residual fluid in a storage tank.



Worst Case Scenario: Worst case scenario assessment has been made and potential off-site consequence

analysis (OCA) was undertaken. However, in conformance with Office of Emergency Management guidance, the OCA for worst-case and/or alternative release scenario(s) has not been included in this Executive Summary because of security concerns.



Accident Prevention Program

Given the lack of proximity to offsite receptors and lack of accidents, McGinness Hills is registered as a program level 1 stationary source.  Notwithstanding the program level, Ormat maintains a complete accident prevention program as specified for a program level 3 facility, at all plants.



Safe Work Practices: Safe work practices have been developed and implemented to provide for the control of hazards during work activities such as lock out/tag-out, confined space entry, opening process equipment or piping, and control over entrance into a facility by maintenance, contractor, laboratory or other support personnel. These safe work practices apply to both employees and contractors.



Maintenance Procedures: A Mechanical Integrity Program (MIP) has been initiated at the McGinness Hills

facility. The MIP adopted a maintenance concept for periodic preventative and corrective maintenance of the OEC system at McGinness Hills. The preventative maintenance tasks include visual inspection, lubrication of rotating parts, system cleaning, replacing liquids and filters, and periodic tests to verify that the system is in proper operating condition. Preventative maintenance tasks and procedures are scheduled to be undertaken over a series of maintenance intervals.  Alarm system maintenance is determined using a combination of regulatory requirements, manufacturer's recommendations, plant operating experience and best practices. 



Training: Initial training for personnel is given before that employee is allowed to either handle n-pentane,

operate or work o

n the facility's process area or on process equipment. Initial training shall be completed

with Emergency Services Personnel including a tour of the site, gas and fire detection system operations, and familiarization with the motive fluid characteristics.



Refresher training is conducted on an annual basis, at a minimum, and when review of the chemicals or

process reveals a need for additional training. Initial and refresher training, associated with the Risk Management Program, is documented and maintained per the requirements of the Training Program.  Additional training will also be provided as needed or requested by Emergency Services Personnel. Contracted employees, shall be trained in the requirements of the EAP procedure prior to working at the McGinness Hills site. Training will include the following items, but is not limited to: (a) Location and sounds of the stand down, and evacuation alarms; (b) Expectations of response to injuries and emergencies by personnel on site; and (c) Evacuation routes and locations. Refresher training for all personnel shall be conducted annually at a minimum.



Safety Training: Some equipment at the McGinness Hills Geothermal Power Plant poses potential fire, explosion, and electrical hazards that could cause serious personal injuries and costly property damage if safety procedures are not followed correctly. Safety training, conducted monthly and required of all employees, identifies the different hazards to be found on the sites. These subjects include Emergency Action Plan (EAP), motive fluid hazards, fire prevention and hot work, lock out and tag out procedures, hazard communication, confined space, hearing conservation, personal protective equipment, accident, injury and incident reporting. Safety training is supplemented by the use of the Standard Safety Procedures.



n-Pentane system: Deviation from the design limits of operation for the n-pentane transfer system will not normally occur since the individual compone

nts are rated beyond the highest achievable values of pressure, temperature, and flow within the system.



OEC Units: The OEC units are controlled and monitored by their own dedicated HMI Programmable Logic

Controller (PLC). The PLC receives all discrete (logic) and analog signals from the input devices (e.g. switches and measuring sensors), processes the signals according to pre-loaded Ormat software, and then outputs logic and analog command signals to local and field devices. All parameters needed for proper operation of the OEC units, such as pressure, temperature, voltage, current, power, speed, etc. are measured by the proper measuring instruments. Deviation from the operating parameters will immediately be detected by the PLC and the PLC will initiate correction or automatic shutdown of the related OEC unit. Under normal circumstances, no releases or other dangerous situations are expected to result from these automatic actions. Appropriate manual override is provided.



Relief system design: Relief valves are located on the n-pentane storage tanks and on the OEC vaporizers and condensers. Each pressure relief valve relieves directly to atmosphere, and some installations have extension pipes installed to direct the relief valve discharge away from critical machinery. 



Ventilation System Design: All components of the n-pentane transfer and storage systems and the OEC units are located outdoors.



Safety Systems: Beyond the relief system the McGinness Hills, the OEC units have extensive fire protection, gas and flame detection, and alarm systems.  These protective systems, in conjunction with the administrative control system, ensure the focus is upon fire prevention.



The fire detection systems include gas monitors which continuously monitor the area surrounding the OEC's, and ultraviolet/infrared flame detectors throughout the plant. The facility has a fire water system installed in a continuous loop around the generating units and within reach of th

e n-pentane storage tanks and major process equipment. The fire water systems consist of fire monitors and hydrants, and a diesel driven fire pump that draws from a 300,000 gallon fire water tank (nominal capacity). Operators are trained in the proper use of the installed fire protection equipment, and the training information is appropriately documented by the facility operator.



Process Hazard Analysis

A Process Hazardous Analysis (PHA) including Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study, an external events

analysis, and a preliminary human factors analysis was undertaken in December 2010, and was  revised several times through April, 2012 for MGH1.  The PHA for MGH2 was completed in February, 2014. The recommendations of the PHA are integrated into the facility and facility operations. The PHA will be updated and revalidated at least every 5 years to ensure the study is consistent for the life of the pentane processes.



Five-Year Accident History

MGH1 has had no accidents reportable pursuant to the RMP criteria.  MGH2 has had no accidents reportable pursuant to the RMP criteria. 



Emergency Response Program

The Emergency Response Program is intended to identify and coordinate personnel in the event there is an emergency. The EAP procedures apply to all personnel working at the McGinness Hills facility. The EAP has been submitted to the local fire department and LEPC for review and their concurrence when changes are made to the plan. 



Implementation, Control and Compliance: The Plant Manager has overall responsibility for the development and implementation of the Emergency Action Plan. The Emergency Action Plan is reviewed annually to verify regulatory compliance and accuracy with both OSHA Regulations on Emergency Plans 29CFR1910.38 and CAPP's Emergency Response Programs, NAC 459.9544. The Emergency Response Program must also be periodically reviewed and updated and employees notified of any changes in conformance with 40 CFR 68.95. The EAP may also be re

viewed, as part of any Incident Investigations or when deemed required during Management of Change. Current copies of the Emergency Action Plan are located in the McGinness Hills Control Building and in the company's electronic data base.



Evacuation of Personnel: In the event of an emergency determined to be n-pentane system related and

evacuation is deemed necessary, the control room operator or other designated personnel will sound the

plant evacuation alarm.  Activation of fire and gas detectors are also interlocked to sound the alarms automatically.



First Aid: All personnel have been trained in adult CPR and basic first aid procedures.



Control Room Operator: Upon notification from the site that an emergency has occurred, the Control Room Operator shall verify that appropriate response activities have been initiated and emergency response teams have been called. The Control Room Operator assumes initial communications with site over emergency situations until relieved by either the Plant Manager or Operations Manager.



Emergency Response Personnel: Fire, police, and/or ambulance crews will be called if necessary. The senior employee on site at the time of the incident will give a report to the person in charge of the emergency teams.  The emergency response personnel assume the role of incident commander upon arrival on scene.



Planned Changes To Improve Safety

PHA recommendations that were made to improve operations or safety have been implemented.
